DOC.detailed_description: BACKGROUND : Apnea prematurity ( AOP ) common problem preterm infant . Nasal respiratory support use either Continuous Positive Airway Pressure ( CPAP ) Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation ( IMV ) , among others , widely use treatment . Which different system efficient , however , unclear . OBJECTIVE : Efficiency different CPAP system reduce cumulative percentage bradycardia desaturation preterm infant . METHODS : In prospective , randomize , cross-over trial 32 preterm infant Infants randomly allocate receive nasal CPAP deliver one follow sys-tems : ( 1 ) conventional IMV-System ( Stephanie , Stephan GmbH , Germany PIP 15 cmH2O , RR 10/min ) deliver CPAP via short binasal prong ( Hudson RCI , USA ) ; ( 2 ) Infant-Flow-System ( EME Ltd , Great Britain ) CPAP delivery via short binasal prong ; ( 3 ) Infant-Flow-AdvanceTM-System use pressure assist mode PIP 10 cmH2O , RR 10/min ; ( 4 ) nasal underwater bubble CPAP application via binasal prong ( Hudson RCI , USA ) . All system adjust achieve approximate PEEP 6 cm H2O . Each study last 24 hour , chest wall abdominal movement , SaO2 , tcPCO2 , ECG , esopha-gus pressure CPAP-/IMV-pressure record continuously . Infants study room air 15° head tilt prone position treat caffeine ( 3mg/kg/d ) . PRIMARY OUTCOME MEASURE Cumulative percentage bradycardia ( heart rate < 80/min ) desaturation ( SaO2 < 80 % ) per hour .
